Executive Summary
  1a.  Introduction
The Northwest Wastewater Treatment Plant, operated by the City of Springfield, has a
capacity of 6.4 million gallons per day.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the
section 112 regulated substances maintained at the Northwest Wastewater Treatment
Plant, which will be referred to here in as the Plant.

  1b.  Background Information
This Contingency Plan describes procedures in place at the Northwest Wastewater
Treatment Plant to minimize the possibility of an emergency situation.  This plan also
provides response procedures to be implemented in emergencies to minimize hazards
to human health or the environment from any unplanned sudden release of hazardous
chemicals to the air, soil or surface water.
It is necessary to amend the plan if:
1.)  The applicable regulations are revised;
2.)  The plan fails in an emergency;
3.)  The facility design, constriction or operations changes significantly;
4.)The list of emergency personnel changes; or
5.)The inventory or location of emergency equipment changes.  

This plan is prepared in a format so that the information may be easily updated      and
photocopied for educational purposes.  This plan and all  revisions to the        plan are
to be kept at the Plant and regularly updated throughout the        operating life of the
facility.
  Contingency plan information is kept in the Control Room at Wastewater Treatment
Plant.  Copies and updated information are provided to local authorities and emergency
teams, as may be called upon, to provide emergency 
service.
Any questions concerning this plan should be directed to Ed Malter, Superintendent of
Sanitary Service at the
Southwest Treatment Plant
3301 S. Hwy. FF
Springfield, MO.  65807
or phone at 417-891-1600 Ext 121.











  1c.  Plant Description
The Wastewater Treatment Plant is an activated sludge plant designed to handle 6.5
MGD.  The Plant maintains two regulated substances on site:  chlorine and sulfur
dioxide.  These

chemicals are used for disinfection and de-chlorination.  The
maximum chlorine stored on site is 16,000 pounds, which exceeds the RMP
threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds for chlorine.  The maximum sulfur dioxide stored
on site is 8,000 pounds, which exceeds the RMP threshold quantity of 5,000 pounds
for sulfur dioxide.  The storage and management of both chlorine and sulfur dioxide
are addressed in this RMP.  The Plant is located at   4801 N. State Highway 13,
Springfield, Missouri, which is a rural area.  The surrounding area includes some
scattered residences.  The Plant is about 2.5 miles north of Interstate Highway 44,
the main highway that leads into Springfield and .25 miles off the west side of State
Highway 13.

  1d.  Accident History
The Plant has had no chlorine or sulfur dioxide releases in the past 5 years.  In the
28 years, chlorine has been used for disinfection at the Northwest Treatment Plant,
there have been no releases that would have required this contingency plan to be
implemented.



2.  The Worst Case Release Scenario
The worst-case release scenario for chlorine was calculated as the release of a
single one-ton cylinder in accordance with the definition provided in the
Environmental Protection Agency guidance for RMP development.  Only passive
control systems can be considered for the worst-case release, such as the
containment provided by a building.  The conditions of the scenario, such as release
time and weather status are those provided in the EPA Off-site Consequence
Analysis Guidance.  The area of potential impact was determined using RMP*Comp
modeling software developed by the EPA.

The results of the worst case Off-Site Consequence analysis indicated that the
chlorine would travel approximately 2.2 miles under the specified weather conditions
before dispersing in the atmosphere to a harmless concentration.  The sulfur dioxide
would travel approximately 2.1 miles before dispersing to a harmless concentration. 
Since the toxic endpoint f

or the chlorine release is farther away, it was used at the
worst case scenario.  Within that radius of the Plant, an estimated 1,540 persons
could potentially be affected.  Maps of the area and a list of the types of receptors in
the potential impact area are provided in the Off-Site Impact Analysis Section.

This type of release would only occur if the cylinder valve was broken off, or the
cylinder was breached.  The likelihood of such an incident occurring is minimal.



3.  Alternative Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario is, by definition, a more likely release scenario than
the worst case.  Engineered controls, such as detection systems, automatic tank
shutoff valves, alarms, or scrubbers are considered in the analysis.

   The type of system failure selected for the chlorine alternative release was the loss
of chlorine due to a break in the flexible tubing leading from the cylinder to the
vacuum regulator.  The chlorine would leak from a 3/8" opening.  The leak would
continue until the chlorine detection alarm sounded and the valve on the cylinder
could be closed. The automatic tank shutoff valves would close in less than 5
seconds after alarm was activated.  Because chlorine would have leaked into the
chlorine room, the Springfield Fire Dept. would respond according to their
procedures for a toxic chemical release.  The time for the response was estimated at
10 minutes for the first Fire Department truck to be on the site.  The time for the
response was estimated at 15 minutes for the first Fire Department Ha

z-Mat truck to
be on the site.  Once on site, the fire response personnel would enter the room in
protective clothing and close the valve on the leaking cylinder. 

   The type of system failure selected for the sulfur dioxide alternative release is very
similar to chlorine release because the two chemicals are stored in identical tanks
and are applied with the same type of feed equipment.  The scenario was the loss of
sulfur dioxide due to a break in the flexible tubing leading from the cylinder to the
vacuum regulator.  The chemical would leak from a 3/8" opening.  The leak would
continue until the detection alarm sounded and the valve on the cylinder could be
closed.  Because sulfur dioxide would have leaked into the room, response would be
made by the Springfield Fire Department according to their procedures for a toxic
chemical release.  The time for the response was estimated at 10 minutes.  Once on
site, the fire response personnel would enter the room in protective clothing and
close the valve on the leaking cylinder.
    The results of the Alternative Release Off-Site Consequence Analysis using
RMP*Comp, indicated that the chlorine would travel approximately 0.7 miles under
the specified weather condition in order to disperse in the atmosphere to a harmless
concentration.  Within the larger of these two distances from the Plant, an estimated
100 persons could potentially be affected.  Maps of the area and a list of types of
receptors in the potential impact area are provided in the Off-Site Impact Analysis
Section.  The list of potential receptors includes: 
 

  3a.  The list of potential receptors includes:
      a.  Ritter Springs (Park)
      b.  Carpet Barn
      c.  All Star Gas
      d.  Sac River Trail
                                      (See area map included)    
       
              
4.       Process Hazard Assessment
A process hazard assessment was performed on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide
systems beginning with cylinder unloading and endi

ng with each chemical in
solution.  A combination checklist and modified a what if type of analysis was used. 
General questions regarding the storage and use areas as well as practices and
protocols associated with the management of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide system
were answered.  A copy of the checklist is including in this plan.  Following the
checklist, each system was methodically evaluated valve by line from the cylinder to
point of chlorine injection using system flow diagrams (see flow diagrams 1, & 2). 
The valves and other points in each system where the chemical could be released
are numbered on the flow diagrams.  The assessments are formatted in accordance
with code requirements; considerations of potential failure, maintenance and
inspection concerns, and standard operation procedures were reviewed for each
point in the system.  Comments are summarized in the Process Hazard Assessment
section.

  4a.  Prevention System
The Plant has an operation, maintenance, and inspection system designed to review
each element of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems routinely.  There are
Operation and Maintenance manuals for each major piece of equipment, and
personnel receive significant training before being allowed to work on the system.  At
the beginning and end of the daily operating period, and as each cylinder is
changed, the valves and piping are checked for leaks.  There are standard operating
procedures (SOP) for startup, shutdown, normal operation, and emergency
operation.  The SOPs are written and posted in appropriate areas.  Personnel are
trained routinely on safety concerns and general operation as well as emergency
procedures.
    Each system is equipped with leak detectors and alarms that indicate leaks, air
operated shout off valves activated by alarm condition or power failure.  Exhaust
fans are provided on each chemical storage room and used only when a worker is
present.  Exhaust fans are equipped with an automatic setting that shuts off

exhaust
fans in the case of a leak to confine the chemical to the storage area.
       
5.  Emergency Response Plan
  5a.  Alarm Condition:
In the event the chlorine gas content in ambient air reaches or exceeds the alarm
level of the gas detectors, external alarm circuits are energized.  Red alarm light
goes on outside of the room with the alarm condition, audible alarms sound.  Alarm
lights and audible alarm in the main office are also activated. Air operated motors
close the tank valves. 
    During times the Plant is not staffed, Atlas Security is notified by phone line from
the Plant PLC, in the Operations building.  Atlas Security is able to tell the
differences between an intruder, mechanical and chemical alarm.
The alarm will continue to sound even after the alarm condition has been
acknowledged every fifteen minutes for two seconds at a time, until the chlorine is no
longer at alarm levels and the detectors are able to be reset.  If the chlorine gas level
in the atmosphere has not decreased below the alarm level, pressing the reset
button will not extinguish the Red alarm light or audible alarms.  After all chlorine gas
has been removed from the atmosphere, wait 4-5 minutes or more to allow the
chlorine in the sensor to completely dissipate before resetting the detector.  When
pressing the reset button, do not hold the button in for more than one second or the
detector may not reset.  If after the gas has dissipated, the detector cannot be reset
and placed back in service, contact your supervisor.

  5d.  Hazardous Chemicals at the Wastewater Treatment Plant
 A list will be kept at the Plant of chemicals with corresponding Material Safety Data
Sheets, for processes associated with wastewater treatment whether used in large or
small quantities.

The list will include location of the chemicals at the facilities.  See
appendix for list and locations of chemical.  The facility drawings of each building
show location of the chemicals and safety equipment.
  5e.  Emergency Plan Procedures
 In the event an emergency chemical release situation develops at the 
facility, the following procedures will be followed:

1.)  During normal hours when Plant staff are present:  In the event of an
emergency situation, call 911 immediately, to alert the Springfield Fire Department
that a chemical release (indicating what type of chemical has been released) has
occurred at Springfield's Northwest Treatment Plant.  Then Plant staff will appraise
the leak conditions, wind direction to determine if the site needs to be evacuated
immediately upwind and to higher ground.  Plant staff will then proceed down the
Emergency Call List notifying the appropriate city staff, while continuing to monitor
the environmental conditions.

All City Fire Department and Haz-Mat team personnel listed as Emergency
Response Personnel are thoroughly familiar with Contingency Plans, the location
and characteristics of hazardous chemicals, the location of all records within the
facility, and the facility layouts.

    All City Plant personnel listed as Emergency Response Personnel are to be Haz-
Mat certified to Operational level and are thoroughly familiar with all aspects of the
facility's Contingency Plans, all operations and activities at the facility, the location
and characteristics of hazardous chemicals, the location of all records within the
facility, and the facility layouts.  The Emergency Coordinators have authority to
commit resources of the City to deal with emergencies at the facility and if more
appropriate to the situation, will summon help from other employees.


6.  Implementation of the Contingency Plan Assessment 
All employees at the Northwest Treatment Plant are required to be Haz-Mat certified
to Operational level and will respon

d and assist as training allows.  Any response
requiring entry into a dangerous atmosphere or use of a chlorine tank repair kit is to
be managed by the Springfield Fire Department Haz-Mat team.  The Plant has an
agreement with the Springfield Fire Department; a copy of this agreement is
included.  The decision to implement the Contingency Plan will be made if it is
determined that the conditions are unsafe during the hours staff is on duty or if the
alarm conditions occurs during time when the Plant is not manned.
     The Springfield Fire Department will assume control when arriving at the Plant.
The Fire chief on the scene or senior Haz-Mat official on scene will be the on-scene
Incident Commander.  Plant and Public Works staff will assist as required.

The Contingency Plan shall be implemented due to a SPILL or CHEMICAL
RELEASE if:
1.)  The spill or leak endangers human health or the environment , on-site or off-        
  site.
2.)  The spill or leak could result in on-site or off-site soil contamination and/or            
    ground or surface water contamination.
3.)  The spill or leak could release toxic or flammable liquids or vapors, thus               
  causing a fire or gas explosion hazard.  The potential exists for incompatible          
chemicals to come in contact with each other. 

When the decision is made to implement the Contingency Plan, the 
Emergency Coordinator or designee will direct or complete the directions outlined in
the following sections of this plan, which describes procedures, emergency
equipment, coordination agreements, and evacuation plans.

  6a.  Contingency Plan Implemented
If the Contingency Plan must be implemented, the Emergency Response Personnel
will initiate the following procedures:
1.)  Evaluate the circumstances of the alarm condition.  Greene Country    Sheriff
Department may be needed for evacuation of surrounding area. The Emergency
Response Personnel will immediately identify the characteristics, source, amount,
a

nd area extent of the release.  Because hazardous chemicals are stored in distinct
areas and because drum or other contents are labeled, the chemicals involved and
affected by the emergency situation should be readily identifiable.

2.) If Springfield's Fire Department has arrived, they will have assumed control. 
Plant personnel will assist as needed.  If the Fire Department has not arrived,
proceed to the next step.

3.) City staff responding from Atlas Security call will proceed to the Plant, and will,
after evaluating wind direction (the wind sock is located South East of the chlorine
building mounted under the light on a 30 foot light pole, be visible at night from
outside the plant) and other environmental conditions.  Assure that all appropriate
city and county responders on the Emergency Call List have been notified.

 (The Emergency Response Personnel should be called in the order they are
listed.  (Charles Parrott, Ed Malter, Jim Noblitt, the LEPC, etc.)

4.) Isolate area, set perimeters, deny entry to all non emergency personal . 
Evacuate the area, affected building (s) or, if necessary, the entire facility.  Proceed
UPWIND and OUT OF LOW AREAS.  Evacuate area as needed to higher ground up
wind.
5.) If equipment systems are involved, shut them down if such action can be done
without putting personnel at risk.

  6b.  Identification of Hazardous Chemicals
1.)  During the emergency the Emergency Response Personnel shall undertake all
reasonable measures necessary to ensure that discharges do not spread to other
hazardous chemicals at the facility.  These measures may include, stopping
processes and operations, collecting and containing released chemicals and
removing or isolating containers.
2.) Immediately after an emergency, the Safety Coordinator should provide for
containing and disposing of recovered chemicals, contaminated soil or surface water
or any other material that results from the discharge.
3.)  No chemical waste that may be incompatible with

the released chemical is stored
at the facility until clean-up procedures are completed;
4.)  Emergency equipment listed in the Contingency Plan is to be leaned and fit for
its intended use prior to resuming normal operations.

1.) If a facility ceases or changes operation in response to a discharge, the
Supervisor or plant personnel shall notify DNR about changes in operating
conditions.   Ed Malter or appropriate personnel shall be responsible for notifying:

safety person must notify the appropriate state and local authorities that the following
have been compiled with, in accordance with 40 CFR 265.56:

Within legal limits (from 24 hours to 15 days, depending on the release) the Risk
Manager shall submit a written report of the event to all appropriate agencies.  The
written report shall include: 
 a.  Name, address, and telephone number of owner and operator.  
 b.  Name, address, and telephone number of facility.
 c.  Date, time, and type of accident.
 d.  Type and quantity of chemicals involved. 
 e.  The extent of injuries (if any) or possible hazards to human health or
  environment outside of the facility. 
             f.  The estimate of quantity and disposition of hazardous chemicals that          
              resulted from the incident. 
             g.  Assessment of actual and potential hazards.

Emergency Spill or Leak Control Procedures to follow after 911 and Emergency

vernment Emergency Notification Telephone Numbers

     4.     If the spill/leak is small, take appropriate action to contain the flow of the gas
     or liquid.  Trained personnel wearing appropriate chemical protective gear
     should only attempt this action.
     5.     Provide information to the Fire Department and Haz-Mat Team, upon their
        arrival, concerning the spilled/leaking chemicals (s).  Upon arrival the Fire     
  Department or Haz-Mat unit will be in charge.  Public Works safety

     6.     Haz-Mat Team wearing appropriate protective gear should conduct air

     7.     Efforts to contain the spill/leak should be initiated or continued, if applicable.

     8.     Pump large amounts of contained chemical to drums for disposal.  Small

  disposal.  Trained personnel wearing appropriate protective gear should            
  only attempt this action.
     9.     Clean all contaminated surfaces, including drums, containment structures, 
     containers and ancillary equipment.  Clean-up personnel must wear            
     appropriate prote

ctive gear.
     10.    Decontaminate all response personnel protective gear, equipment, and
     apparatus.  Wearing of appropriate protective gear is required during
     decontamination operations.


7.  Post-Incident Procedures
    The Safety Coordinator must record every spill on the Supervisor=s Incident
Investigation Report.  The Risk Manager along with Safety Coordinator and the Plant
management will review the report to determine what action should be taken to
prevent similar occurrences in the future.  Other reports are required by law and are
discussed in subsequent paragraphs.

  7a.  Floods  
    The hazardous chemicals management activities at the Wastewater Treatment
Plant are located outside the 500-year flood plain; therefore; exceeding the flood
stage will be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

  7b.  Evacuation Plans
   In an uncontrolled emergency, all persons are to be evacuated from the area. 
Evacuation should proceed UPWIND AND OUT OF LOW AREAS.  The Plant
intercom system will be used to notify all personnel of the emergency.  Operators are
trained in what equipment and systems may need to be shut down.  During
evacuation, a check by the supervisor must be made to ensure that all personnel are
accounted for and out of the dangerous area.
    Information from the North American Emergency Response Guidebook related
to evacuation distances, is provided in Appendix A.

  7c.  Record Keeping and Reporting
Emergencies are recorded and maintained as part of the operating record. 
Leaks/spills or other incidents are recorded on a Supervisor's Incident Investigation
Report form and are filed as required.  A spill or releases, if of a minor or controllable
nature, will not necessarily require implementation of the Contingency Plan.
    If full implementation of the Contingency Plan is implemented, then within 
 15 days or statutory limits of full implementation of the Contingency Plan, the Risk
Manager shall submit a written report to the appropriate

agencies.  The report shall
include the following information:
            > Name, address, and telephone number of facility, owner and operator.
            > Date, time and type of accident
            > Type and quantity of chemicals involved.
            > The extent of injuries (if any) or possible hazards to human health or             
          environment outside the facility.
            > The estimate of quantity and disposition of hazardous chemicals that             
          resulted from the incident.
            >  Assessment of actual and potential hazards.

       Proper use of protective gear, to include the SCBA, emergency response
       measures and emergency telephone numbers.  New personnel will be
       trained and certified to the Haz-Mat operations level.

      9.  Arrangements with Local Authorities
     The requirements of 40 CFR 265.37 call for the Treatment Plant to make
arrangements to familiarize police, fire departments, and emergency response teams
with the layout of the facility, properties of the hazardous chemicals at the facilities,
places where personnel would be normally working, entrances to and roads inside
the Plant, and possible evacuation routes.  To fulfill this responsibility, the City of
Springfield, MO.  Has sent a copy of this Contingency Plan to the Police and Fire
Departments, Greene County Sheriff Department, Local Emergency Planning
Committee and invited them to visit the plant and discuss its operation in more detail. 
The police, fire departments and Local Emergency Planning Committee will be
notified of any subsequent changes made to this Contingency Plan.
